been a while! How were your holidays? Did you get some rest? </p>\n\n\n\n\n\n<p>Wishing you and yours a Happy, healthy and prosperous New Year! May all the goals be reached and serendipity take you to new adventures. </p>\n\n\n\n<p class=\"has-text-align-center has-large-font-size\">   </p>\n\n\n\n<p>Now we need to catch up on the development and community around Gutenberg. What a long list again! It&#8217;s a feature of the persistent medium of a blog or an email,  you don&#8217;t have to consume it all in one sitting. You can come back to it every day. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>Glad you are here again! </p>\n\n\n\n<p>Yours, <br />Birgit</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n<h2>Gutenberg and Page Builders</h2>\n\n\n\n<p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/kylevandeusen\"><strong>Kyle Van Deusen</strong></a> shared his experience building a simple Landing Page with Elementor and then built the same page with Gutenberg with a helping of <a href=\"https://generateblocks.com/\">GenerateBlocks plugin</a>. In his post<strong> <a href=\"https://theadminbar.com/damn-gutenberg-smokes-elementor/\">&#8220;</a></strong><a href=\"https://theadminbar.com/damn-gutenberg-smokes-elementor/\">Damn. Gutenberg Smokes Elementor&#8221;</a>, you can read more about the process, challenges and speed metrics measured via GTMetrix as well as with Lighthouse. </p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/karks88\"><strong>Eric Karkovack</strong></a> published his <a href=\"https://speckyboy.com/page-builder-wordpress-gutenberg-block-editor/\">take on switching from a page builder</a> (here: Visual Composer) to a Gutenberg-based site, the challenges he encountered and how he solved them. </p>\n\n\n\n<h2>Gutenberg Plugin Releases</h2>\n\n\n\n<p>Two new plugin versions were released: <strong>Gutenberg <a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/core/2020/12/23/whats-new-in-gutenberg-23-december/\">9.6</a></strong> and<strong> <a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/core/2021/01/07/whats-new-in-gutenberg-6-january/\">9.7</a></strong>. The <a href=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/podcast\">Gutenberg Changelog</a> episode covering both versions will be available later this weekend. Meanwhile, WPTavern has you covered: </p>\n\n\n\n<ul><li><a href=\"https://wptavern.com/gutenberg-9-7-improves-user-experience-updates-reusable-blocks-and-brings-page-templates-to-fse-themes\">Gutenberg 9.7 Improves User Experience(&#8230;)</a></li><li><a href=\"https://wptavern.com/gutenberg-9-6-introduces-drag-and-drop-blocks-and-global-inheritance-for-the-query-block\">Gutenberg 9.6 Introduces Drag-and-Drop Blocks (&#8230;) </a></li></ul>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Anne McCarthy</strong> has more details and a video on the new Drag and Drop features in the Block editor: <a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/core/2021/01/08/core-editor-improvement-drag-drop-blocks-and-patterns-from-the-inserter/\">Core Editor Improvement: Drag &amp; Drop Blocks and Patterns from the Inserter</a>  &amp; </p>\n\n\n\n<h2>Full-Site-Editing</h2>\n\n\n\n<p>Right after the release of Gutenberg 9.6, <strong>Anne McCarthy </strong>called upon participants of the <a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/test/2020/12/23/fse-program-testing-call-1-template-editing/\">FSE Outreach program to test specific parts of the full-site-editing experience</a> and report back their findings. You can still participate in this first test. The deadline is January 13, 2021. </p>\n\n\n\n<p><em>Learn more about the program <a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/core/2020/12/11/the-fse-outreach-program-is-officially-starting/\">here </a>and <a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/test/handbook/full-site-editing-outreach-experiment/faq-for-fse-outreach-experiment/\">here</a>, and in the separate WP Slack channel </em><a href=\"https://wordpress.slack.com/archives/C015GUFFC00\">#fse-outreach-experiment</a></p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p>For setting up local tests <strong><a href=\"https://twitter.com/cdils\">Carrie Dils</a> </strong>published a <a href=\"https://carriedils.com/full-site-editing-blueprint-for-local/\">Full-Site-Editing Blueprint for Local</a> by Flywheel, now Local Lightening.</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n<p><strong>On ThemeShaper, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/jcristpbking\">Jason Crist</a> </strong>published the 3rd part of &#8220;Get Started with Block Themes&#8221; tutorial. He covered <a href=\"https://themeshaper.com/2021/01/08/getting-started-with-block-themes-global-styles/\">how the new feature Global Styles come into play.</a>  &#8220;An important goal of Global Styles is to make it easier for users to change how their site looks without having to know or write any CSS.&nbsp;&#8221; He explains the new global settings, naming conventions, how to set global and block styles not only via JSON file of your Theme. You also learn how users could change them via the Sidebar in the new <a href=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/site-editor-demo-sotw/\">Site Editor </a>screen. Jason has links to an empty theme and the themes experiments repo and also to the developer documentation. </p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p>Apropos, Global Styles,<strong><a href=\"https://twitter.com/itsJonQ\"> Jon Quach</a></strong> has and update for us on the Implementation of the new G2 Components. Now you can follow along on the <a href=\"https://g2components.wordpress.com/2021/01/07/integration-status/\">progress on this project via the beautiful new Status page.</a></p>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n\n<p>Triggered by audience questions, <strong><a href=\"https://twitter.com/justintadlock\">Justin Tadlock</a></strong> ventured into the details of the Query Block in his post <a href=\"https://wptavern.com/understanding-the-query-block-and-its-importance-in-site-editing\">&#8220;Understanding the Query Block and Its Importance in Site Editing&#8221;</a>.</p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p>During last year&#8217;s State of the Word, <strong>Joen Asmussen</strong> demonstrated the <a href=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/site-editor-demo-sotw/\">Site Editor screen.</a> He showed us how to edit template parts, or change the Global Styles or the Archive pages. </p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p>Join us on <strong>January 29th, 2021 at 11 am ET / 16:00 UTC</strong>  (<span class=\"has-inline-color\">Changed date!</span>) for our <strong><a href=\"https://us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/8916060629467/WN_vtNXZ0zTTs2S0S98X0Y9og\">Gutenberg Times Live Q &amp; A: Update on the WordPress Site-Editor (TNG)</a></strong><br />We will talk with <strong>Carolina Nymark</strong> back, our resident expert on Full-site Editing as well as <strong>Ari Stathopoulos</strong>, Core Contributor and who landed the first block-based theme, Q, in the repository and <strong>Anne McCarthy</strong>, from Full-Site editing outreach program. We&#8217;ll have the latest updates on Full-Site-Editing, block-based Themes and Global Styles for you and answer all your questions. </p>\n\n\n\n<h2>Gutenberg outside of WordPress.</h2>\n\n\n\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://twitter.com/ftrain\">Paul Ford</a> and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/ginatrapani\">Gina Trapani</a> of PostLight</strong>, a WordPressVIP agency,  discussed with Matt Mullenweg the expansion of WordPress and his love for open source. <a href=\"https://postlight.com/podcast/wordpress-and-beyond-with-matthew-mullenweg\">In the podcast episode  &#8220;WordPress and Beyond&#8221;</a>, Mullenweg &#8220;shared controversial opinions on open source and explains why well all be headed there in the future.&#8221; It&#8217;s one of the more thoughtful conversations on the web and open-source. They also cover the aspect that Gutenberg can be integrated into non-WordPress sites and CMS. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>Matt said: <em>&#8220;(&#8230;) Were actually re-licensing Gutenberg to the MPL, which is the<a href=\"https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/MPL/\"> Mozilla Public License</a> to allow it to be used in proprietary mobile apps. So, the idea is that a Mailchimp or WordPress or Tumblr, a Drupal, a Facebook all can utilize this.&#8221; </em></p>\n\n\n\n<p>The whole episode is a great listen for web workers of the 21st century. </p>\n\n\n\n<h2>Plugins for the WordPress Block Editor</h2>\n\n\n\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://twitter.com/timmyblog\">Tim Toomey</a></strong>, and the team at Covertnine has been busy updating their <a href=\"https://wordpress.org/plugins/c9-blocks/\">C9 Blocks plugin</a> and <a href=\"https://wordpress.org/themes/author/ttoomey/\">themes</a> with <a href=\"https://c9.covertnine.com/c9-animation-plugin/\">Animations</a>. They also published a <a href=\"https://2021.covertnine.com\">demo site </a>with the Twenty Twenty One theme and their plugins installed.</p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://twitter.com/artpi\">Artur Piszek</a></strong> released a new plugin for the block editor: <a href=\"https://wordpress.org/plugins/roam-block/\">Roam Research Block</a> &#8211; This block lets you search and embed&nbsp;<a href=\"https://roamresearch.com/\">Roam Research</a>&nbsp;blocks inside WordPress block editor. I started using Roam Research a week ago, and I found a complete more organic way to organize my thoughts, my writing, my bullet lists and notes for projects. I am in the process of migrating approx 2800 notes from Evernote. That has its challenges, but I will move ahead as the hassle is absolutely worth it.  Artur has more details about the <a href=\"https://deliber.at/wp-roam-block/\">WordPress plugin on his blog </a></p>\n\n\n\n<h2>Block Development</h2>\n\n\n\n<p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/justinfoell\"><strong>Justin Foell</strong></a>,  shared his thoughts on <a href=\"https://webdevstudios.com/2020/12/29/wordpress-blocks-backwards-compatibility/\">WordPress Blocks Backwards Compatibility </a>on the WebDevStudios blog. There are several things to consider: React versions, Gutenberg plugin versions, version of the @wordpress/packages, to name just a few. </p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/gziolo\"><strong>Greg Zikowski</strong></a> published the tutorial &#8220;<a href=\"https://gziolo.pl/2020/12/22/how-to-start-block-development-with-scaffolding/\">How to Start Block Development with Scaffolding&#8221;</a> and walks you through the use of the official create-block script. The command line tool gets you started on a single-block plugin with all PHP, JavaScript and CSS files wired up for the plugin directory and the block editor. Greg walks you through various sections and how to customize the templates for our processes. </p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/nickmdiego\"><strong>Nick Diego</strong></a> write <a href=\"https://nickdiego.com/a-primer-on-wordpress-slotfill-technology/\">&#8220;A primer on WordPress SlotFill technology&#8221;</a>. Slot and Fill together with the <code>SlotFillProvider</code> are available for developers to extend the Block Editor in JavaScript. </p>\n\n\n\n<h2>WordPress Events</h2>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>January 22, 2021  24-hour event</strong><br /><strong><a href=\"https://www.wordfest.live/register/\"><em>The</em>&nbsp;festival of WordPress  WordFest</a></strong><br />The <a href=\"https://www.wordfest.live/schedule/\">session and schedule</a> are now posted. The format is 30 min pre-recorded w/ 15 min Q &amp; A, so attendees can interact with the speakers live. There are over 45 sessions on four stages. The Global stage runs talks for the full 24 hrs. Holy Cow! </p>\n\n\n\n<p>I am looking forward to connecting with the audience for my talk on 1/22 at 4 pm ET / 21:00 UTC <a href=\"https://www.wordfest.live/sessions/case-study-a-nocode-contributor-journey-on-the-wordpress-gutenberg-github-repo/\">&#8220;Case Study: A #Nocode Contributor Journey On The WordPress Gutenberg GitHub Repo&#8221;</a>. </p>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Daisy Olsen</strong> will also give a block editor related talk: <a href=\"https://www.wordfest.live/sessions/extending-the-wordpress-editor-with-block-patterns/\">Extending the WordPress Editor With Block Patterns</a> (11 pm ET on 1/21 / 2:00 UTC &#8211;  I will need to catch it on the re-run). </p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p><strong>January 30February 14, 2021 </strong><br /><strong><a href=\"https://india.wordcamp.org/2021/\">WordCamp India</a></strong><br />Yes! You read those dates right.&nbsp;The Organizers plan to have our WordCamp over three weekends!&nbsp; It will be a fully online event</p>\n\n\n\n<ul><li>January 30  31&nbsp;  Workshop Days</li><li>February 6  7  Contributor Days</li><li>February 13  14  Speaker Talks</li></ul>\n\n\n\n<p><em>Featured Image: Photo by&nbsp;<a href=\"https://unsplash.com/@single_lens_reflex?utm_source=unsplash&utm_medium=referral&utm_content=creditCopyText\">Dan Burton</a>&nbsp;on&nbsp;<a href=\"https://unsplash.com/s/photos/building-blocks?utm_source=unsplash&utm_medium=referral&utm_content=creditCopyText\">Unsplash</a></em></p>\n\n\n\n\n<form class=\"wp-block-newsletterglue-form ngl-form ngl-portrait\" action=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/feed/\" method=\"post\"><div class=\"ngl-form-container\"><div class=\"ngl-form-field\"><label class=\"ngl-form-label\" for=\"ngl_email\">Subscribe with your email address</label><div class=\"ngl-form-input\"><input type=\"email\" class=\"ngl-form-input-text\" name=\"ngl_email\" id=\"ngl_email\" /></div></div><button class=\"ngl-form-button\">Subscribe</button></div><div class=\"ngl-message-overlay\"><div class=\"ngl-message-svg-wrap\"></div><div class=\"ngl-message-overlay-text\">Thanks for subscribing.</div></div><input type=\"hidden\" name=\"ngl_list_id\" id=\"ngl_list_id\" value=\"26f81bd8ae\" /><input type=\"hidden\" name=\"ngl_double_optin\" id=\"ngl_double_optin\" value=\"yes\" /></form>\n\n\n\n<p>We will use this email address only to send you the Gutenberg Times Weekend edition and invitations to Live Q &amp; A events. You will receive a request for confirmation to your email address from pauli@gutenbergtimes.com. Once you confirm there, your subscription will be complete. </p>\n\n\n\n\n<p><br /></p>\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Thu, 30 Sep 2021 18:15:09 +0000\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:32:\"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/\";a:1:{s:7:\"creator\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:18:\"Birgit Pauli-Haack\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}}}i:38;a:6:{s:4:\"data\";s:13:\"\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:39:\"Gutenberg Times: Site Editor Demo #SOTW\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:35:\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/?p=16135\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:49:\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/site-editor-demo-sotw/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:12135:\"<p>During State of the Word 2020, Joan Asmussen gave a 3-minute demo of the beta-version of the Site Editor that will come to WordPress as part of the Full-Site Editing experience in 2021. There are a few places where you can catch the whole State of the Word. This post is about the Site-Editor demo. </p>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-container-61588b37dc8bf wp-block-group alignwide has-background\"><div class=\"wp-block-group__inner-container\">\n<h2>State of the Word 2020 </h2>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-columns alignwide\">\n<div class=\"wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top\">\n<p class=\"has-small-font-size\">This year, Matt Mullenweg, co-founder of WordPress and CEO of Automattic gave his keynote from home. He reviewed the year 2020. Afterwards, he and other members of the WordPress team answered questions from the community. The event was livestreamed on Dec. 17, 2020. </p>\n</div>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-column\">\n<ul class=\"has-small-font-size\"><li>Video: <a href=\"https://wordpress.tv/2020/12/17/matt-mullenweg-2020-state-of-the-word/\">Matt Mullenweg&#8217;s State of the Word 2020</a> (26 min) </li><li>Video: <a href=\"https://wordpress.tv/2020/12/17/matt-mullenweg-2020-state-of-the-word-qa/\">State of the Word 2020 Question &amp; Answers</a> (61 min)</li><li><a href=\"https://wptavern.com/state-of-the-word-2020-wordpress-moves-toward-full-site-editing\">State of the Word 2020: WordPress Moves Toward Full Site Editing</a> (WPTavern)</li><li><a href=\"https://mailchi.mp/poststatus/426?e=e31bffca27\">Excellent summary and background information</a> by David Bisset in the Post Status newsletter. </li></ul>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div></div>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p>Joen Asmussen, one of the designers on the Gutenberg project from the beginning, did a walk-through of the current version of the Site Editor. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>Matt said: <em>&#8220;2021 makes it easier than ever to get your vision onto your site, and your site onto the web. And now we&#8217;d like to show you a sneak peek at some of what&#8217;s coming around the corner with Gutenberg.&#8221;</em> </p>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-embed__wrapper\">\n<div class=\"toolbelt-video-wrapper\"></div>\n</div><a href=\"https://bit.ly/SotW2020\">Excerpt of the State of the Word 2020 </a>\n\n\n\n<p class=\"has-text-align-center has-small-font-size\"><em><a href=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/feed/#transcript\">Full Transcript is below</a></em></p>\n\n\n\n<p>For his demo, Joen used the theme <a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/theme-experiments/tree/master/tt1-blocks\">Twenty-Twenty-One Blocks Theme (TT1-Blocks)</a>. The team is preparing this year&#8217;s default theme, Twenty-Twenty One, for the release of the full-site editing experience in 2021. You can find it in the <a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/theme-experiments\">Theme Experiments</a> Repo on GitHub. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>To use the theme yourself you need to install the <a href=\"https://wordpress.org/plugins/gutenberg/\">Gutenberg plugin</a>, and the full-site-editing experience will be available to you after activating the TT1-Blocks theme or any other block-based themes from the themes-experiments. </p>\n\n\n\n<p class=\"has-text-color has-background has-small-font-size\">&#8220;Warning: Full Site Editing is an experimental feature and potential API changes are to be expected!&#8221;</p>\n\n\n\n<p>The full-site experience comprises the Site-Editor, Navigation  &amp; Widget Screens and Global Styles sidebar. You can read about the current status of development of each part in Matias Ventura&#8217;s post <a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/core/2020/12/10/status-check-site-editing-and-customization/\"><strong>Status Check: Site Editing and Customization</strong></a> </p>\n\n\n\n<p>I also want to point out that the speed in which Joen change screens and reloads his updates seems a wee bit faster than in real life. It will depend heavily on the oomph of your server and Internet speed how fast you can navigate and change settings on the editor. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>The first feature, Joen points out is the <strong>Query Block</strong>, a feature rich block for the Loop &#8211; a list of posts or pages or other content types, displayed on the homepage or on archive pages. The already available &#8220;Latest post&#8221; block is its first iteration. The query block will give users and theme developers alike great flexibility with an easy integration and customization process. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>Without knowing the technical terms, you can change the Site Title, the Navigation and the tagline right from the Site Editor screen. Use the <strong>Block List View</strong> to orient yourself and jump directly to the various sections of your site. Behind the scenes, the <strong>Site Editor Engine</strong> keeps track of all your edits, displays them in a sidebar overview and save the various parts and template at the right places. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>You can pull into the Site-Editor any kind of template, Joen mentions the default error handling page (also 404-page), and modify it with existing blocks and familiar tools. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>With a Theme&#8217;s <strong>block patterns</strong>, you should have a set of ready-made templates you can add to your site&#8217;s footer or pages for various display options.</p>\n\n\n\n<p>The <strong>Global Styles</strong> controls in the sidebar of the site editor allow you to make decision on the color palette of your site and you can review your pages and posts on how they change the design on the fly.</p>\n\n\n\n<p>After watching this demo, I can only echo Matt&#8217;s &#8220;(&#8230;) We&#8217;ve come a long, long way with Gutenberg from those first versions you might&#8217;ve seen and tried out. If you haven&#8217;t given a try recently, I encourage you to check out Gutenberg.&#8221; I have been following the project with you here on the Gutenberg Times for the last three years and I can still get excited about the new features the team adds to the editor to make it a tool of creativity on the web. </p>\n\n\n\n<h2>Live Q &amp; A: WordPress Site-Editor (TNG)  Jan 28, 2020</h2>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-image\"><img />Ari Stathopoulos</div>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-image\"><img />Carolina Nymark</div>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-image\"><img />Anne McCarthy</div>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>In our next Live Q &amp; A</strong>, we will have <strong>Carolina Nymark</strong> back, our resident expert on Full-site Editing as well as <strong>Ari Stathopoulos</strong>, Core Contributor and who  landed the first block-based theme, Q,  in the repository and <strong>Anne McCarthy</strong>, who runs the Full-Site editing outreach program. We have the latest updates for you on <strong>January 28th, 2020 at 11am ET / 16:00 UTC</strong> &#8211; <a href=\"https://us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/8916060629467/WN_vtNXZ0zTTs2S0S98X0Y9og\">You can already reserve your seat</a>. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>Until then, enjoy our previous discussions on Full-Site Editing and block-based themes.  Or browse through the show notes of the Gutenberg changelog podcast next door. Each episode comes with a ton of links to resources. </p>\n\n\n\n<h2>Discussions on Block-Based Themes with Theme designers and Gutenberg developers</h2>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-media-text alignwide has-media-on-the-right is-stacked-on-mobile is-image-fill has-dark-gray-color has-text-color has-background\"><a href=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/live-q-a-block-based-themes-for-full-site-editing-feature-in-wordpress/\"><img /></a><div class=\"wp-block-media-text__content\">\n<p class=\"has-normal-font-size\"><br /><a href=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/live-q-a-block-based-themes-for-full-site-editing-feature-in-wordpress/\"><strong>Block-based WordPress Themes / Full Site Editing</strong></a> with Carolina Nymark, Kjell Reigstad and Eileen Violini <br /><em>June 2020</em></p>\n</div></div>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-media-text alignwide has-media-on-the-right is-stacked-on-mobile is-image-fill has-dark-gray-color has-text-color has-background\"><a href=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/theme-templates-full-site-editing-experience-enrique-piqueras/\"><img /></a><div class=\"wp-block-media-text__content\">\n<p class=\"has-normal-font-size\"><a href=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/theme-templates-full-site-editing-experience-enrique-piqueras/\"><strong>Themes and the Full Site Editing experience for WordPress (experimental)</strong></a> with Enrique Piqueras<br /><em>January 2020</em></p>\n</div></div>\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-block-media-text alignwide has-media-on-the-right is-stacked-on-mobile is-image-fill has-dark-gray-color has-text-color has-background\"><a href=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/rethinking-themes-in-wordpress/\"><img /></a><div class=\"wp-block-media-text__content\">\n<p class=\"has-normal-font-size\"><strong><a href=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/rethinking-themes-in-wordpress/\">Rethinking WordPress Themes</a> </strong>with Ellen Bauer, William Patton, and Rich Tabor<br /><em>December 2019</em></p>\n</div></div>\n\n\n\n<p class=\"has-large-font-size\" id=\"transcript\">Transcript </p>\n\n\n\n<p>Matt Mullenweg: 2021 makes it easier than ever to get your vision onto your site, and your site onto the web. And now we&#8217;d like to show you a sneak peek at some of what&#8217;s coming around the corner with Gutenberg. We have Joen showing the site editor beta.</p>\n\n\n\n<p>Joen Asmussen:&nbsp; In this demo, I&#8217;d like to walk you through the new Gutenberg site editor. The site editor allows you to edit the theme templates beyond the post content. It introduces several new blocks like the query loop. When you make a modification like adding a featured image, it naturally adds it to every post in the query. You can configure the layout, make simple tweaks, and it propagates to all the posts. If you prefer the featured image above the titles, no problem. All the familiar block interactions are available.</p>\n\n\n\n<p>While the header is a separate template part, it could be edited seamlessly. Everything is a block, navigation, the site title, the tagline, making it easy to edit anything and make use of all the block tools available. The block list view shows all the different areas like header and footer for quick access. Since everything is created with blocks, it&#8217;s easy to edit. The site editor engine keeps track of all the modifications, giving the user a clear overview of what has been modified. The site title, the header area, etcetera. You can open the 404 template, modify it like any other content. With the introduction of block patterns to WordPress, themes will be able to offer any number of designs, providing a shortcut to replicating demo sites or swapping out aspects users may not like with another that they do.</p>\n\n\n\n<p>This is the culmination of several ongoing projects to improve and expand upon the customization possibilities in WordPress. Both templates and regular pages can be edited in the site editor. Small previews can be seen when hovering the different templates. The style customization panel allows making global changes like text, link, or background color. These modifications can be quickly checked against the different pages in the site. You can customize any template of the site, such as the page template. Drag and drop the page title into a cover block to use a gradient for that page. The possibilities are endless. We can&#8217;t wait to see what you build with this.</p>\n\n\n\n<p>Matt Mullenweg: As you can see, we&#8217;ve come a long, long way with Gutenberg from those first versions you might&#8217;ve seen and tried out. If you haven&#8217;t given a try recently, I encourage you to check out Gutenberg. By creating this common framework that every theme and plugin can build on we&#8217;re reducing the Balkanization within WordPress from people who are solving these problems lots of different ways, and providing what I believe is the basis for the next decade of WordPress&#8217;s growth. So we&#8217;re about two years into a 10 year project. We&#8217;ve got good chunks of phase one and phase two of Gutenberg done. That&#8217;s the post and page editing and then editing the entire site. I&#8217;m excited to continue these in 2021 and hopefully start to get to phases three and four.</p>\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Thu, 30 Sep 2021 18:15:09 +0000\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:32:\"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/\";a:1:{s:7:\"creator\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:18:\"Birgit Pauli-Haack\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}}}i:39;a:6:{s:4:\"data\";s:13:\"\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:105:\"Gutenberg Times: Weekend Edition #152-Block-Based Themes, G2 Components, Block Pattern Directory and more\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:35:\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/?p=16062\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:71:\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/weekend-edition-152-block-pattern-directory/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:13491:\"<p>Happy Holidays! </p>\n\n\n\n<p>It&#8217;s almost there, in less than two weeks, we leave 2020 behind us and start the New Year! Wishing you and yours all the best for this new beginning, good health, prosperity and happiness. </p>\n\n\n\n\n\n<p>Yours, <br />Birgit</p>\n\n\n\n<h2>State of the Word</h2>\n\n\n\n<p>This week&#8217;s State of the Word was different from the previous years, as it didn&#8217;t come with a whole room full of WordPress enthusiast at a WordCamp US. This year it was <a href=\"https://wordpress.tv/2020/12/17/matt-mullenweg-2020-state-of-the-word/\">a short sweet 26 minutes keynote by Matt Mullenweg</a> with appearances of Joen Asmussen demoing the Site Editor and Josepha Haden introducing successful businesses that started because of the pandemic. &#8220;When online is your only options, WordPress is your best option&#8221;. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>The <a href=\"https://wordpress.tv/2020/12/17/matt-mullenweg-2020-state-of-the-word-qa/\">Question &amp; Answer session</a> was also different: WordPress Community members were asked to send in their questions via video, and instead answering all the questions himself, Matt deferred to other members on the WordPress teams. It was high diversity crowd coming together. </p>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Sarah Gooding</strong> wrote a <a href=\"https://wptavern.com/state-of-the-word-2020-wordpress-moves-toward-full-site-editing\">full recap for the WPTavern</a>. </p>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>David Bisset</strong> also posted an <a href=\"https://mailchi.mp/poststatus/426?e=e31bffca27\">excellent summary with some background information on the Post Status</a> newsletter. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>Here on the <a href=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/site-editor-demo-sotw/\">Gutenberg Times</a>, I was most intrigued by the demo of the beta version of the Site-Editor by Joen Asmussen. <a href=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/site-editor-demo-sotw/\">You can read all about here.</a></p>\n\n\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Learn.WordPress</strong> was officially launched with over 30 Workshops and Discussion groups. Let Hugh Lashbrooke <a href=\"https://wordpress.org/news/2020/12/introducing-learn-wordpress/\">introduce you to the new program</a>. We have a  <a href=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/block-editor-workshops-wordpress/\">list of Block Editor Workshops</a>, for beginners and advanced content creators and developers. </p>\n\n\n\n<p><a href=\"https://wptavern.com/g2-components-a-from-scratch-reimagining-of-wordpress-components?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=g2-components-a-from-scratch-reimagining-of-wordpress-components\">G2 Components, a From-Scratch Reimagining of WordPress Components</a> (WPTavern) <br /><strong>Justin Tadlock</strong> wrote about  Jon Quach&#8217;s new component design system, G2 Components, that has been in the works for the last six months. It&#8217;s about to start bleeding into the Gutenberg @wordpress/components script, with switching out the base components one at a time, without breaking 3rd party developers plugins. At least that&#8217;s the idea of it. Jon and the Gutenberg team is carefully walking the backwards compatibility line. The developer experience around the block-editor will get a major upgrade once the G2 components are successfully integrated. They will not only be available for the block-editor but of other wp-admin interfaces as well. </p>\n\n\n\n<h2>Block-based Themes (aka Full-Site-Editing)</h2>\n\n\n\n<p><a href=\"https://wptavern.com/jump-start-block-based-theme-development-with-the-fse-theme-generator\">How to use the scaffolding script to start your new block-based theme</a>, is the topic of <a href=\"https://wptavern.com/jump-start-block-based-theme-development-with-the-fse-theme-generator\">this article </a>in the WPTavern by Justin Tadlock. He walks you how to get started and then use the Gutenberg site-editor to finish the theme. It&#8217;s a bar bones theme, of course, a fresh canvas for designers. Justin then digs into the various pieces of the generated theme. </p>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Carolina Nymark</strong>, contributor to the Themes team and educator at <a href=\"https://fullsiteediting.com\">full-site-editing.com</a>, started the &#8220;<a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/themes/2020/12/14/discussion-requirements-for-full-site-editing-themes/\">Discussion: Requirements for full site editing themes</a>&#8221; for themes to be approved to the official Themes repository on WordPress.org. </p>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Ernesto Mendez</strong> wrote Part II in ThemeShaper&#8217;s series of <a href=\"https://themeshaper.com/2020/12/18/getting-started-with-block-themes-templates/\">Getting Started with Block Themes on Templates</a>. He explained: &#8220;In the classic way of theming, we usually have functions that give us the different parts that make up a post, such as&nbsp;<code>the_title()</code>,&nbsp;<code>the_content()</code>, and so on. Block themes give us the same features using blocks directly!&#8221;. Ernesto also shared shared more about the difference between a classic WordPress theme and a block-based one and walks you through creation, saving and editing of the various pieces. </p>\n\n\n\n<p><a href=\"https://wptavern.com/help-steer-the-future-of-wordpress-via-the-fse-outreach-program\">Help Steer the Future of WordPress via the FSE Outreach Program</a> &#8220;The official launch of the program should coincide with the release of Gutenberg 9.6, which is expected to ship within the next week. The program will focus on specific features and flows related to full-site editing.&#8221; wrote<strong> Justin Tadlock</strong></p>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Kjell Reigstad</strong> published is #32 <a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/themes/2020/12/18/gutenberg-themes-week-of-dec-14-2020/\">Gutenberg + Themes: Week update</a> of ongoing development. He keeps us updated on the latest discussions and issues that can use your input. Also, his list of Overview Issues and Resources is a treasure chest. <br />I just discovered an article I missed in by Ari Stathopoulos: &#8220;<a href=\"https://wp.me/p29gdg-4MC\">Printing navigation-block HTML from a legacy menu in themes</a>&#8221; Something really helpful when you might need to migrate a site from a classic theme to a block-based theme. If you are up for a theme experiment, earlier this month, Kjell published a <a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/theme-experiments/pull/120\">Photo blog theme for blocks</a></p>\n\n\n\n<h2 id=\"patterns\">Block Pattern Directory</h2>\n\n\n\n<p>Speaking of WordPress.org Directory: Late in October, Alex Shiels kicked of the work on a <a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/meta/2020/10/27/block-pattern-directory-ideas-and-discussion/\">Block Pattern Directory ideas and discussion</a>. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>The meta-team hasn&#8217;t been wasting any time. You can follow along on the <a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/pattern-directory\">GitHub repository</a> and its <a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/pattern-directory/projects/1\">project board for the initial version</a>. Similar to the Block-directory, there are a few moving pieces that need to fit together: </p>\n\n\n\n<ul><li><a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/pattern-directory/issues/11\">The website of the Pattern Directory for WordPress.org</a>, similar to on the plugin and themes directories. </li><li><a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/pattern-directory/issues/10\">Pattern Directory support in the core editor</a> so users can search and insert block patterns directory from the inserter, similar to the block directory, without the installation steps. Patterns probably can be directly added to the post or page from the directory. </li><li><a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/pattern-directory/issues/9\">Pattern Submission Tool</a> &#8211; based on the editor with sidebar controls and metadata entry. This will include <a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/pattern-directory/issues/22\">a validation and curation step</a> before the submitted pattern is published. You can also follow along the <a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/pattern-directory/issues/9#issuecomment-724362494\">first designs by Michael Arestad</a>. This is probably the most exciting part of the new directory as it will accommodate the community&#8217;s creativity. </li><li><a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/pattern-directory/issues/8\">Pattern Directory API for the backend of the site</a></li><li><a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/pattern-directory/issues/3\">REST-API end-point</a>, and </li><li><a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/pattern-directory/issues/30\">new Pattern CPT permissions for creation and editing</a> </li></ul>\n\n\n\n\n\n<h2>Developing for the Block Editor</h2>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Ronald Huereca</strong> published a 12 part series on <a href=\"https://wpandajax.com/series/building-a-gutenberg-sidebar/\">&#8220;Creating a Gutenberg Sidebar&#8221;</a> plugin. He wrote: &#8220;Building sidebars is hard and not very straightforward.&#8221; In he walks you through how to get&nbsp;<a rel=\"noreferrer noopener\" href=\"https://webpack.js.org/\" target=\"_blank\">webpack</a>&nbsp;set up so you can create a sidebar without the use of any boiler-plate-type scripts. This is set up as a basic course to create a plugin for WordPress, in general and for the block-editor specifically.  </p>\n\n\n\n<h2>WordPress Events</h2>\n\n\n\n\n<div class=\"wp-container-61588b37e1e15 wp-block-group\"><div class=\"wp-block-group__inner-container\">\n<p><strong>December 22, 2020 a 6:30 pm ET &#8211; 23:30 UTC</strong><br /><strong><a href=\"https://www.meetup.com/SF-WordPress-Users/events/275108037/\">WordPress Mega-Meetup </a></strong></p>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>David Bisset</strong> wrote on <a href=\"https://twitter.com/dimensionmedia/status/1339685263036080128\">Twitter: </a>&#8220;What is some place to chill next week? Try the <a href=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/feed/#WordPress Mega-Meetup\">#WordPress Mega-Meetup</a>. Host Jean Felisme and me will be talking with Birgit Pauli-Haack about Gutenberg and WordPress 5.6 and playing some WP games. Thanks to meetup organizers and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/GoDaddyPro\">GoDaddy Pro</a> for supporting us.&#8221; </p>\n</div></div>\n\n\n\n\n<p><strong>January 22, 2021  24-hour event</strong><br /><strong><a href=\"https://www.wordfest.live/register/\"><em>The</em>&nbsp;festival of WordPress  WordFest</a></strong><br />Enabling a global celebration of WordPress, bringing our community together in a safe environment, whilst facilitating freedom of movement within a 24-hour virtual event. The organizers just announced the <a href=\"https://www.wordfest.live/speakers/\">first, second, third and fourth set of speakers</a>, among them <a href=\"https://www.wordfest.live/speakers/leonardo-losoviz/\">Leonardo Losoviz</a>, <a href=\"https://www.wordfest.live/speakers/chris-ford/\">Chris Ford</a>, <a href=\"https://www.wordfest.live/speakers/fatima-sarah-khalid/\">Fatima Sarah Khalid</a>, <a href=\"https://www.wordfest.live/speakers/naomi-c-bush/\">Naomi C. Bush</a>, <a href=\"https://www.wordfest.live/speakers/piccia-neri/\">Piccia Neri</a> and so many more. Can&#8217;t wait until the organizer publish the list of sessions. The format is 30 min pre-recorded w/ 15 min Q &amp; A, so attendees can interact with the speakers live. </p>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>January 28th, 2021 at 11 am ET / 16:00 UTC</strong> <br /><strong><a href=\"https://us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/8916060629467/WN_vtNXZ0zTTs2S0S98X0Y9og\">Gutenberg Times Live Q &amp; A: WordPress Site-Editor (TNG)</a></strong><br />We talk with <strong>Carolina Nymark</strong> back, our resident expert on Full-site Editing as well as <strong>Ari Stathopoulos</strong>, Core Contributor and who landed the first block-based theme, Q, in the repository and <strong>Anne McCarthy</strong>, who runs the Full-Site editing outreach program. We&#8217;ll have the latest updates on Full-Site-Editing, block-based Themes and Global Styles for you and answer all your questions. </p>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>January 30February 14, 2021 </strong><br /><strong><a href=\"https://india.wordcamp.org/2021/\">WordCamp India</a></strong><br />Yes! You read those dates right.&nbsp;The Organizers plan to have our WordCamp over three weekends!&nbsp; It will be a fully online event</p>\n\n\n\n<ul><li>January 30  31&nbsp;  Workshop Days</li><li>February 6  7  Contributor Days</li><li>February 13  14  Speaker Talks</li></ul>\n\n\n\n<p><a href=\"https://india.wordcamp.org/2021/call-for-speakers/\">The call for speakers will be open until December 31, 2020.</a></p>\n\n\n\n\n<form class=\"wp-block-newsletterglue-form ngl-form ngl-portrait\" action=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/feed/\" method=\"post\"><div class=\"ngl-form-container\"><div class=\"ngl-form-field\"><label class=\"ngl-form-label\" for=\"ngl_email\">Subscribe with your email address</label><div class=\"ngl-form-input\"><input type=\"email\" class=\"ngl-form-input-text\" name=\"ngl_email\" id=\"ngl_email\" /></div></div><button class=\"ngl-form-button\">Subscribe</button></div><div class=\"ngl-message-overlay\"><div class=\"ngl-message-svg-wrap\"></div><div class=\"ngl-message-overlay-text\">Thanks for subscribing.</div></div><input type=\"hidden\" name=\"ngl_list_id\" id=\"ngl_list_id\" value=\"26f81bd8ae\" /><input type=\"hidden\" name=\"ngl_double_optin\" id=\"ngl_double_optin\" value=\"yes\" /></form>\n\n\n\n<p>We will use this email address only to send you the email Gutenberg Times Weekend edition and invitations to Live Q &amp; A events. Only once you confirm there will your subscription be complete. </p>\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:7:\"pubDate\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:31:\"Thu, 30 Sep 2021 18:15:09 +0000\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}s:32:\"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/\";a:1:{s:7:\"creator\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:18:\"Birgit Pauli-Haack\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}}}}i:40;a:6:{s:4:\"data\";s:13:\"\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";s:5:\"child\";a:2:{s:0:\"\";a:5:{s:5:\"title\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:116:\"Gutenberg Times: Weekend Edition #151  Theme Development, Block Editor Plugins and Using Blocks Outside WordPress\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"guid\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:35:\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/?p=15946\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:4:\"link\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:68:\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/weekend-edition-151-block-editor-plugins/\";s:7:\"attribs\";a:0:{}s:8:\"xml_base\";s:0:\"\";s:17:\"xml_base_explicit\";b:0;s:8:\"xml_lang\";s:0:\"\";}}s:11:\"description\";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:\"data\";s:17495:\"<p>Howdy! </p>\n\n\n\n<p>WordPress history was made this week, when the all-women release squad pushed WordPress 5.6 over the finish line. Congratulations to the co-leads,  Josepha Haden, Helen Hou-Sandi and Dee Teal and their crew of 30+ women and people who identify as non-binary.  <a href=\"https://wordpress.org/news/2020/12/simone/\">On the announcement post, </a>you can browse the list of all contributors and follow the links to their profiles. I know, I know. You are here to read about the block editor and Gutenberg. I will get to that in a minute. </p>\n\n\n\n\n<ul><li class=\"blocks-gallery-item\"><img /></li><li class=\"blocks-gallery-item\"><img /></li></ul>WordPress 5.6 Noteworthy Contributors.\n\n\n\n\n<p>Let&#8217;s marvel a moment longer at the astonishing First of an all-women release squad for a major WordPress release, the open-source project that powers <a href=\"https://w3techs.com/technologies/overview/content_management\">over 39% of the Internet.</a> </p>\n\n\n\n<p class=\"has-text-align-center\">     </p>\n\n\n\n<p>Back to the block-editor. The many links and information in this edition might be a bit overwhelming. It will tide you over the upcoming quiet time around the Holidays. Don&#8217;t forget to scroll all the way down to learn about the upcoming WordPress events. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>Next week (#152) will be the last Gutenberg Times Weekend Edition for 2020. I will take a break for two weeks from work and WordPress. It&#8217;s the time of year to catch-up with close friends and family and plan for the uncertainty of 2021 in business and life.  On Jan 9th, we&#8217;ll start the new year with edition #153. </p>\n\n\n\n\n<form class=\"wp-block-newsletterglue-form ngl-form ngl-portrait\" action=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/feed/\" method=\"post\"><div><div><label class=\"ngl-form-label\" for=\"ngl_email\">Subscribe with your email address</label><div><input type=\"email\" class=\"ngl-form-input-text\" name=\"ngl_email\" id=\"ngl_email\" /></div></div><button class=\"ngl-form-button\">Subscribe</button></div><div><div></div><div>Thanks for subscribing.</div></div><input type=\"hidden\" name=\"ngl_list_id\" id=\"ngl_list_id\" value=\"26f81bd8ae\" /><input type=\"hidden\" name=\"ngl_double_optin\" id=\"ngl_double_optin\" value=\"yes\" /></form>\n\n\n\n<p>We will use this email address only to send you the email Gutenberg Times Weekend edition and invitations to Live Q &amp; A events. You will receive a request for confirmation to your email address from pauli@gutenbergtimes.com. Only once you confirm there will your subscription be complete. </p>\n\n\n\n\n<p>Now, don&#8217;t let me keep you from watching videos, reading tutorials, editorials testing plugins and themes and register for awesome WordPress events. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>Until next week, stay safe and warm.</p>\n\n\n\n<p>Yours, <br />Birgit</p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5ejk24_XWeI\"><img /></a>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Recording: <a href=\"https://youtu.be/5ejk24_XWeI\">Case Study: The Making of Open-Source Story by Yoast with Blocks</a></strong></p>\n\n\n\n<p>We had a fabulous time chatting with Yoast partner and CTO, Omar Reiss and content team lead Willemien Hallebeek, who took us behind the scenes of the making of the <a href=\"https://yoast.com/open-source-story/\">Open-Source Story</a>, a richly illustrated and interactive post about the nature of open-source from a collaborative business point of view. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>Thanks for everyone who joined us and brought some great questions. A big Thank You to Anne McCarthy, who joined me as co-host and moderator.</p>\n\n\n\n<p><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5ejk24_XWeI\">The video is now on YouTube</a> with the shared resources. The transcript is in the works. </p>\n\n\n\n<p>And &#8220;Welcome&#8221; to our new subscribers, who came for the show and stayed for the Weekend Edition.  So happy to have you! </p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n\n\n<p><strong>The Gutenberg team</strong> has changed their release cycle slightly. Instead of 2 days between Release Candidate and new version, they give themselves and others 7 days to tests the new version. This changed the schedule a bit for the next release. </p>\n\n\n\n<ul><li>9.6 will be released on Dec. 23 (RC on Dec. 16th) </li><li>9.7 will be released Jan 6th, with RC on Dec. 30th) </li></ul>\n\n\n\n<p>Mark and I will be on holiday break and our next episode of the Gutenberg Changelog podcast will be recorded on January 8th, 2021, and cover both releases. </p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p>To bridge the time, I suggest you read two posts by <strong>Matias Ventura</strong>, architect for Gutenberg and learn more about the current state of affairs. </p>\n\n\n\n<p><a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/core/2020/12/10/status-check-site-editing-and-customization/\"><strong>Status Check: Site Editing and Customization</strong></a><br />It&#8217;s an excellent summary of the current status of Gutenberg&#8217;s Phase 2. It&#8217;s a bit longer, you probably should get another cup of hot beverage and get comfortable reading in. It definitely is worth your time. </p>\n\n\n\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/issues/27331\">Sidebar Controls &amp; Component System</a></strong><br />&#8220;The first half of this year brought some needed updates to the design language of blocks, with a strong focus on improving the block footprint, toolbar system, and the inserters. Now its time to revise the state of block controls primarily used in the sidebar and its underlying component set. This is the next widest topic for the evolving design language.&#8221; wrote Ventura. </p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n\n\n<h2>Theme Development</h2>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Kjell Reigstad</strong> published the <a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/themes/2020/12/11/gutenberg-themes-week-of-dec-7-2020/\">31st update on Gutenberg + Themes</a> with the week&#8217;s discussion on theme related issues, updates and fixes to theme related editor aspects. Towards the end he also lists these &#8220;Overview&#8221; issues: </p>\n\n\n\n<ul><li>Full Site Editing Milestones.&nbsp;<a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/issues/24551\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">24551</a></li><li>Template Tags in Full Site Editing.&nbsp;<a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/issues/22724\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">22724</a>&nbsp;</li><li>Missing query block functionality.&nbsp;<a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/issues/24934\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">24934</a> </li><li>Query and Loop block tracking:&nbsp;<a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/issues/24762\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">24762</a></li></ul>\n\n\n\n<h3>Full-Side Editing</h3>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Anne McCarthy</strong> headlined: <a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/core/2020/12/11/the-fse-outreach-program-is-officially-starting/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\"><strong>The FSE Outreach Program is Officially&nbsp;Starting!</strong></a>. You might remember the call for WordPress users to test the Full-Site-Editing experience in Spring. It&#8217;s now time to get ready.  </p>\n\n\n\n<p>If you build, manage or maintain sites for yourself or others or if you publish content using WordPress, join the program! It is a great opportunity to shape the next big change coming to WordPress in 2021. We will be testing specific workflows every week and discuss them with a cohort of people as well as with the Gutenberg team. This is not for developers, but WordPress users who don&#8217;t use code to built their sites. Go on, <a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/core/2020/12/11/the-fse-outreach-program-is-officially-starting/\">read the article.</a> I wait  </p>\n\n\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Carrie Dils</strong>, Freelancer Coach,  published the <a href=\"https://studiopress.blog/full-site-editing-update/\"><strong>Full Site Editing Update for Studio Press</strong></a>. After a short introduction, she went into more detail on each of these moving pieces and highlighted the aspects most relevant to full site editing.&nbsp;</p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p>In his post, <a href=\"https://themeshaper.com/2020/12/09/getting-started-with-block-themes/\"><strong>Getting Started with Block&nbsp;Themes</strong></a>, <strong>Ben Dwyer</strong>, provides you with the first steps to create your block-based Theme, with the Site-Editor in mind. It&#8217;s the first post of a series it seems. Future posts will cover: <a href=\"https://developer.wordpress.org/block-editor/tutorials/block-based-themes/#creating-the-templates-and-template-parts\">Templates</a>,  <a href=\"https://gutenbergtimes.com/the-wordpress-block-patterns-resource-list/\">Patterns</a> and <a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/design/handbook/focuses/global-styles/\">Global Styles</a>. Meanwhile, these links are for your perusal and self-study. </p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://g2components.wordpress.com/about/\">G2 Components</a></strong> started as an experimental project.  It is a from-scratch reimagining of&nbsp;<code>@wordpress/components</code>&nbsp;designed to accommodate the ever-growing and ever-expressive needs of the Editor and the platform.&nbsp;We shared links to the site before. <strong>Jon Quach</strong> and his Gutenberg teammates are getting ready on exploring how and integration into the block editor might work. Let Jon take on you on his <a href=\"https://g2components.wordpress.com/2020/12/02/walkthrough-integration-ideas/\">Walkthrough + Integration&nbsp;Ideas </a> on Twitch, where he holds almost daily live stream while working on this project. </p>\n\n\n\n<img />\n\n\n\n<h3>Twenty-Twenty-One Default Theme</h3>\n\n\n\n<p><a href=\"https://melchoyce.design/2020/12/09/twenty-twenty-one-available-for-download/\">Tweny-Twenty-One is now available for download</a> announced co-lead developer Mel Choyce. She thanked her co-lead Carolina Nymark and all contributors. It&#8217;s an impressive list. This year&#8217;s default theme is <em>WCAG 2.1 AAA-compatible</em>. Here are additional resources: </p>\n\n\n\n<ul><li><a href=\"https://wordpress.org/themes/twentytwentyone/\">Download</a> from the WordPress Theme repository</li><li>The <a href=\"https://wordpress.org/support/article/twenty-twenty-one/\">Documentation</a> of the Theme is now available on the WordPress Support pages. It lists details of all the different features, for accessibility, Starter content, Block Patterns, overlapping columns, support for Post Formats, Dark Mode support, and more. </li><li>The <strong>block-based version</strong> of the Twenty-Twenty-One Theme is still under development and you can follow, test and contribute via the <a href=\"https://github.com/WordPress/theme-experiments/\">GitHub Repository</a></li></ul>\n\n\n\n<p><a href=\"https://www.bluehost.com/blog/twenty-twenty-one-theme-for-wordpress-a-minimal-default-theme-for-2020/\">Twenty Twenty-One Theme for WordPress: A Minimal Default Theme for 2020 </a>  <strong>Machielle Thomas</strong> at Bluehost, wrote about whats new with WordPress Twenty Twenty-One theme and how the new default theme supports block-building. </p>\n\n\n\n<h2>Block editor plugins</h2>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Justin Tadlock</strong> has an update on EditorPlus 2.4 for you: <a href=\"https://wptavern.com/editorplus-2-4-released-builds-upon-its-extend-core-blocks-system\">EditorPlus 2.4 Released, Builds Upon Its Extend Core Blocks System</a></p>\n\n\n\n<p>Just released and also mentioned in our Live Q &amp; A show this week: <a href=\"https://www.multidots.com/google-doc-style-editorial-commenting-for-wordpress/\">Google Doc-Style Editorial Commenting for WordPress</a>, a precursor to Collaboration coming to Gutenberg in Phase 3. </p>\n\n\n\n\n\n<h2>Developing for block editor and Gutenberg</h2>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Igor Benic</strong>, early adopter of the block editor, has some tips for you how to troubleshoot &#8220;<a href=\"https://www.ibenic.com/gutenberg-components-and-invalid-hook-call-error-in-react-what-do-do/\">Invalid Hook Call Error in React&#8221;</a> in your Components. It&#8217;s especially interesting because Igor teaches nice bits about package handling. </p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Antonio Villegas</strong> explored in his post <a href=\"https://neliosoftware.com/blog/how-to-work-with-wordpress-blocks-outside-gutenberg-with-node-js/\">&#8220;How to work with WordPress blocks outside Gutenberg with Node.js&#8221;</a> and provides a short code example. It could open up all kind of opportunities to leverage the modern JavaScript environment in other apps. </p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p><strong>Tim Toomey</strong> and his team at CovertNine, builder of the <a href=\"https://wordpress.org/plugins/c9-blocks/\">C9 Blocks plugin</a>, shared their latest project in the post: <a href=\"https://wpcontent.io/article/building-a-custom-blocks-based-wordpress-website-for-a-client-with-a-free-theme/\">Building a Custom Blocks-based WordPress Website for A Client with A Free Theme</a>, using their creations. You can sign up for early access to their <a href=\"https://greensock.com/\">GreenSock</a> based C9 Animation Blocks plugins</p>\n\n\n\n<h2>Upcoming WordPress and Related Events</h2>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>December 15, 2020  12 pm ET 17:00 UTC</strong><br /><strong><a href=\"https://poststatus.us6.list-manage.com/track/click?u=ff3456b27ebe0be0155087894&id=54a1a1a159&e=e31bffca27\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">5 Tips For Building Rockin Membership Sites</a></strong>  <br />Join Brian Krogsgard and Cory Miller to discuss the secret to successful membership sites. On <a href=\"https://commercejourney.com/\">Commerce Journey</a></p>\n\n\n\n<p><strong>December 15, 2020 at 12:30 pm ET</strong> <strong>/ 17;30 UTC</strong><br /><strong><a href=\"Webinar: Grow Your Agency by Offering SEO Services\">Webinar: Grow Your Agency by Offering SEO Services</a></strong><br />Join Lindsay Halsey of Pathfinder SEO<strong>&nbsp;</strong>as you learn how to package your SEO services, pitching them, and the process to deliver them.&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.gowp.com/\">Hosted by GoWP</a></p>\n\n\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p><strong>December 17, 2020 11am EST / 16:00 UTC</strong><br /><a href=\"https://wordpress.org/news/2020/12/state-of-the-word-2020/\"><strong>State of the Word 2020 w/ Matt Mullenweg</strong></a>, co-founder of WordPress. Livestream on WordPress YouTube, Facebook and Twitter. <a href=\"https://wordpress.org/news/2020/12/state-of-the-word-2020/\">Details here.</a></p>\n\n\n\n<p>Viewing party: <a href=\"https://robertjacobi.com/steak-of-the-word-2020.html\">Steak of the Word 2020</a> organized by Robert Jacobi and Big Orange Heart.</p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p><strong>December 17, 2020 1pm ET / 18:00 UTC</strong><br /><a href=\"Webinar: The 5 W\'s of Decoupled\"><strong>Webinar:</strong> <strong>The 5 W&#8217;s of Decoupled</strong></a> Hosted by Pantheon.<br />Boost Performance and Gain Flexibility Through Decoupled Architecture. Join Pantheons Technical Product Marketing Manager, Steve Persch to learn how decoupling gives you the power of flexibility and access to modern build practices which can provide a significant boost in performance.</p>\n\n\n\n<hr class=\"wp-block-separator is-style-wide\" />\n\n\n\n<p><strong>December 22, 2020</strong> <strong>6:30 &#8211; 8:30 pm EST</strong><br /><strong><a href=\"https://www.meetup.com/SF-WordPress-Users/events/275108037/\">WordPress &#8220;Mega Meetup&#8221;: The &#8220;End of 2020&#8221; Episode</a></strong>  &#8211; David Bisset will be interviewing me about the latest editor and Gutenberg goodies in the latest WordPress 5.6 release.
